HEADER.TITLE: Paddy-dancing — a conversation
La danse du padi — une conversation

S.FORM: narəd lɛ attiatti kɛyuŋma kɛmɛnchiahaˀ mɛwayɛ?
S.TRANSL: Narad, where were your various woman-friends from?

S.FORM: iŋga amɛnchia kɔ khəi ! kurɛm mɛwayɛ.
S.TRANSL: My woman-friends, well!, there have been a lot of them.

S.FORM: amɛnchiahaˀ kohi ɛttho thɔŋlɔŋ kɛyuŋmaaŋ mɛwayɛ.
S.TRANSL: Some were from up here in Thonglong,

S.FORM: kohi ɛttho tho pandɔtluŋ kɛyuŋmaaŋ mɛwayɛ.
S.TRANSL: and some were from up in Pandotlung,

S.FORM: asenba ro! — tərə puraniya kohi ɛtna liŋdhɛppa mɛwayɛ.
S.TRANSL: recent ones — but some of the old ones were from Lingthep.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛaŋ attiatti ɛtyo kohi khɔkliŋbaaŋ mɛwayɛ.
S.TRANSL: And some were from down in Khokling.

S.FORM: tərə ɛmbhɛllɛ khɔkliŋbanu cəĩ anigɛ sɛːrigɛ.
S.TRANSL: But now we've broken off with the Khokling ones.

S.FORM: ɛmbhɛllɛ ɛttho thɔŋlɔŋbanu — liŋdhɛppanu anigɛ sorik wayigɛ.
S.TRANSL: Now we are together with ones from Thonglong, with ones from Lingthep.

S.FORM: khɔmbha ɛtyo thɛdzɔŋbobahaˀci mɛwaˀ.
S.TRANSL: And there are a few from down in Thejongbo.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɔ kɛwayi'llɛ attihaˀrɛ cəĩ khɔmbhɔ kɛwayi'llɛ nurik kɛmmɛtti
S.TRANSL: When you were together, which ones treated you well

S.FORM: attihaˀrɛ cəĩ kɛmɛmmɛttinni nurik?
S.TRANSL: and which ones didn't treat you well?

S.FORM: khan kɔ nurik kɔ ɛmbhɔ ɛttho thɔŋlɔŋb'ɛnnu cəĩ sarik nurik wayigɛ.
S.TRANSL: As for that, we were really getting on well with the Thonglong ones.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛaŋ khanhaˀnu sɛːrigɛ mɛːnni?
S.TRANSL: But then we separated from them, OK?

S.FORM: sɛːrigɛaŋ kɔ ɛtyo thɛdzɔmbobanu tin bərsə the anigɛ sarik nurik wayigɛ.
S.TRANSL: After we separated, for about three years we got along very well with the ones from Thejomboba.

S.FORM: anigɛ nurik mɛmɛttigɛaŋ ciʈʈhi yapmi mɛhaktɛ.
S.TRANSL: They treated us well and they sent us letters.

S.FORM: tərə khɔn mɛnchian allo ɛmbhɛllɛ mədes yo peaŋ yuŋ.
S.TRANSL: But that one has gone down to the plains nowadays.

S.FORM: tərə əru kudzumhaˀ rɔt mɛwaˀ. khɔmbhɛaŋ ɛmbhɛllɛ sɛːrigɛ — khɔnhaˀnu cəĩ .
S.TRANSL: Only her friends are there. But we broke up with them.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛllɛ kunara num'ɛn sira adhaŋ kɛsira thaŋɛi
S.TRANSL: So, do you like ones with pretty faces

S.FORM: ku sor kɛnuˀm'ɛn cəĩ kɛsira thaŋɛi khɛnɛa?
S.TRANSL: or do you like ones with nice voices?

S.FORM: khɔn kɔ ɛmbhɔ ni pha —
S.TRANSL: N. It's like this:

S.FORM: kunara num'ɛn lɔt khɔn sira thaŋba paːnnɛn abhedaŋba phɛllɛ —
S.TRANSL: As far as only liking pretty ones —

S.FORM: jəti khanhaˀnu yaˀ alaːk awaˀ abek həgi —
S.TRANSL: the more we go on dancing with them — isn't that right? —

S.FORM: yaˀ alaːkkɛllɛ khɔn jəstəi aphno thik maya mohə lag ba cok — lag ba cok pek.
S.TRANSL: when we dance, whatever she's like, we are fond of her — we get more and more fond of her.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛaŋ kɔ aphno cal cələn — mɛmma — tɔŋ pek.
S.TRANSL: Our manners — or whatever — come to agree —

S.FORM: hitcit tɔŋ mɛtma poksɛ.
S.TRANSL: our feelings are in harmony, I should say.

S.FORM: cal cələn mɛːndu — hittəcittə — aphno hittəcittə tɔŋɛ.
S.TRANSL: It's not our manners, its our feelings — we sympathise.

S.FORM: tɔŋɛaŋ kɔ alla aphno sor ɛnnaŋ tɔŋɛ.
S.TRANSL: When we sympathize, then our voices harmonize as well.

S.FORM: alla cahe — khallɛ ku ənuhar numa hos tap phɛːnba hos
S.TRANSL: Now her face may be pretty or it may be ugly,

S.FORM: aphno sor ɛnnaŋ tɔŋ— sor ɛnnaŋ tɔŋɛ, aphno hittəcittə aŋ tɔŋɛ.
S.TRANSL: if our voices are in harmony and our thoughts are in harmony

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛ khanhaˀnu cəĩ waˀma sira adhaŋ pek lətchə ni .
S.TRANSL: then it becomes a pleasure to be together with them.

S.FORM: tərə əgaɖi ba khɛni — phɔŋa — ambhɔŋasirɛ khɛni —
S.TRANSL: But in the past, your generation, uncle —

S.FORM: kohi cumlɛ abhe mɛdzogu phɛllɛ
S.TRANSL: Some of our friends, what they did —

S.FORM: kunara num'ɛnnu rɔt yaˀ mɛraːktɛ — yaˀ mɛraːktuba nisuŋ.
S.TRANSL: they only danced with pretty ones — I saw them dance like that.

S.FORM: kohi cumlɛ kunara tap phɛːnbanusaŋ yaˀ mɛraːktɛ.
S.TRANSL: Some danced even with ugly ones as well.

S.FORM: tərə kunara numasaŋ ku sor kɔ tap phɛːnba
S.TRANSL: But though one might be pretty, her voice might be ugly,

S.FORM: — ə̃ — kunara ya tap phɛːnbasaŋ ku sor nuba.
S.TRANSL: and an ugly one might have a nice voice.

S.FORM: khɔmdaŋba mɛnchiahaˀnu attihaˀnu laːkma kɛsira thaŋɛ əghi phɛaŋ kɔ sen tonɛba.
S.TRANSL: So that's why I asked before which women you liked to dance with.

S.FORM: han kɔ ɛmbhɛllɛ cəĩ abhebhɛllɛ iŋga ittuŋŋaŋ khɔm rɔt abhebhɛllɛ aphəi hitcit tɔŋ.
S.TRANSL: Its like this — when I've thought about it its just that — if the feelings are in harmony.

S.FORM: tərə ɛmbhɛllɛsaŋ khɔmdaŋba khunchi cələn waˀ.
S.TRANSL: Even so, some peoples' way is —

S.FORM: theaŋ hop — jun ci caŋ cinuba caksu — mɛːnni? —
S.TRANSL: there's nothing [else that matters]! — whichever one wears nice clothes, OK?

S.FORM: atti'llɛ koʈ ɛmbhɛ jutta ɛmbhɛ nuba caksuaŋ waˀ
S.TRANSL: Whichever one has put on a nice coat and nice shoes,

S.FORM: khallɛ cəĩ khanhaˀnu rɔt yaˀ kɛraːkpaŋ mɛwaˀ kohi kɔ.
S.TRANSL: some people only dance with them.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɔ. tərə ɛmbhɛdaŋba mɔna awaˀ abhedaŋba awaˀ phɛllɛ — ani yakthuŋba awaˀɛllɛ —
S.TRANSL: Just so. But we are like this — what we're like — we Limbus,

S.FORM: kunara tap phɛːnbasaŋ ku sor tap phɛːnbasaŋ theyaːndɔk yaˀ araːk, nurik abaːt aet phɔgɔrɔ
S.TRANSL: even if her face is ugly and her voice is ugly, all the same if we dance and we talk and laugh nicely, day after day,

S.FORM: khɔnnɛn nuba ni tɛt lətchə mɔna'llɛ.
S.TRANSL: why, she seems pretty.

S.FORM: anigɛ əghi khɔmbha wayigɛ'llɛ
S.TRANSL: Before, when we were like that,

S.FORM: khɔmdaŋ khunchi nara tap phɛːnbasaŋ khunchi sor tap phɛːnba saŋ
S.TRANSL: even though their faces were ugly and their voices were ugly,

S.FORM: yaˀ raːkti pegigɛ'llɛ anigɛ nuba nisumsimbɛ mɛnchiahaˀ.
S.TRANSL: when we went on dancing we saw them as beautiful, those women.

S.FORM: ə̃
S.TRANSL: Hmm.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɔ khɔ mɛnchiahaˀ anigɛaŋ nuba mɛnisigɛ.
S.TRANSL: And those women saw us as good-looking too.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛllɔ kɔ khɛnɛ sen tonɛba —
S.TRANSL: So that's why I'm asking you.

S.FORM: abhedaŋ abhedaŋba mɛnchiahaˀ mɛwayɛ
S.TRANSL: What kinds of women were there,

S.FORM: abheabhebhɛllɛ yaˀ kɛraːkti
S.TRANSL: and how did you dance

S.FORM: iŋga sen tonɛba.
S.TRANSL: is what I'm asking you.

S.FORM: tərə khɔn kɔ əgaɖi ba cələn kusik kɔ mɛlɔˀnɛn theaŋ —
S.TRANSL: The custom is not the same as before, because —

S.FORM: ɛmbhɛllɛ cəĩ abhedaŋba
S.TRANSL: how it is nowadays —

S.FORM: asen — alla kɔ ambhɔŋasi səttejug ɛllɛ kɛsusiba ho ki ?
S.TRANSL: before — uncle's generation experienced the golden age, right?

S.FORM: alla səttejug mɛtma anigɛ itm'ɛllɛ səttejug tərə ɛmbhɛllɛ cəĩ
S.TRANSL: Now the golden age — when we think of it it was the golden age, but now

S.FORM: jun lɛ ci caŋ ɛmbhɛba mɛtma nuba caksu — caŋ thehaˀ —
S.TRANSL: whoever wears nicer clothes and so on …

S.FORM: khɔn kɔ khɔmbhɛ a. tərə ɛmbha kɔ mɛːn a.
S.TRANSL: Well, it's like that, but that's not the point.

S.FORM: khɔ jug jug mɛːndukki, — mɔnan kɔ ani lɔtthik —
S.TRANSL: It's not a question of this age or that age, is it? -- we people are the same,

S.FORM: ani nɛksaŋ lɔtthik, mikkaŋ lɔtthik jəmmə kudɔŋba pɔt — mɛːnni?
S.TRANSL: our flesh is the same, our eyes are the same, everything has stayed the same, no?

S.FORM: tərə jug ɛn kɔ khan kɔ mɛːnduk.
S.TRANSL: It's not the age.

S.FORM: tərə khamdaŋba mɔna abhedaŋba abhedaŋba mɛwayɛ.
S.TRANSL: But the kind of people, what kind were they?

S.FORM: abhebhɛllɛ khambha yaˀ kɛraːkti —
S.TRANSL: How did you dance?

S.FORM: abhe abhedaŋba mɛwayɛ phɛaŋ sen tonɛ — pha rɔt ni.
S.TRANSL: What kind of people were there? — I'm asking you.

S.FORM: ɛmbhɛllɛsaŋ uhi sa pha yaˀ raːkmasaŋ uhi .
S.TRANSL: Even so, now, its the same — in dancing, its the same,

S.FORM: hɔnɛ paːnnɛn lɔtcha cɛːtcik pɛni paːnnɛtmu pɔːndɛrɔ — pɔːndɛ lasɛaŋ yak.
S.TRANSL: only the language has got a bit mixed with Nepali — its gotten mixed in —

S.FORM: mɛːŋgɔrɔ əghi kɔ yakthuŋ paːn lɔt paːtmuna.
S.TRANSL: otherwise, before we spoke only Limbu —

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛllɛ khɔn sen tonɛba ni iŋga kɔ. …
S.TRANSL: that's what I'm asking.

S.FORM: khɛnɛ yaˀ kɛraːktɛba iŋga nisuŋŋaŋ wayɛ nirɛŋ sumlɛŋ —
S.TRANSL: I've seen you dancing two or three times.

S.FORM: səŋkranti yaˀ kɛraːktɛ. ramdali yaˀ kɛraːktɛ.
S.TRANSL: You danced at Sankranti, you danced at Ramdali.

S.FORM: yo thuʔyadu kɛbegi khatyo yaˀ kɛraːkti.
S.TRANSL: You all went down and danced at Thukyadu.

S.FORM: taplejuŋ aŋ thiklɛŋ yaˀ kɛraːktuba iŋga nisuŋ.
S.TRANSL: I saw you dance once at Taplejung as well.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛllɛ iŋga khɛnɛ sen tonɛba.
S.TRANSL: So I'm asking you.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛaŋ poŋ tərə the phɛllɛ — ɛmbhɛllɛ cəĩ alla — əgaɖi kɔ khɔmbhɔ wayɛ
S.TRANSL: Thats also true but — before it was like that.

S.FORM: tərə ɛmbhɛllɛ cəĩ — ləu ! the! — ɛmbhɛbhɔ —
S.TRANSL: But now its like this —

S.FORM: caŋwaːn nuba kɛdzaŋba khɔmdaŋba atti ku sor kɛnuˀb'ɛllɔt o mɛmɛttusi hindzaɛllɛ o.
S.TRANSL: The ones that are nicely dressed and have nice voices — the youngsters look at them only.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɔ mɛlɔˀrɛaŋsa sen tonɛba.
S.TRANSL: It's because they say that that I asked you.

S.FORM: hindzaɛllɛ khɔmdaŋba o mɛmɛttusi —
S.TRANSL: The young girls only look at that kind —

S.FORM: attin ʈopi pɛrɛkkɛkkɛkpa khuːksu,
S.TRANSL: whichever one wears a cap at a rakish angle,

S.FORM: atti'llɛ caŋ cinuba caksu,
S.TRANSL: whichever one wears nice clothes,

S.FORM: atti'llɛ ku sor ɛn nuˀ,
S.TRANSL: whichever one's voice is beautiful,

S.FORM: khannɛn lɔt khunchi hindzahaˀrɛ ɛmbhɛllɛ hindzahaˀrɛ o — khanhaˀ — o mɛmɛttusi.
S.TRANSL: they only look at him.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɔ. anigɛ kɔ ɛmbhɔ ʈopi pɛr'kkɛkkɛkpa kɛghuːŋba,
S.TRANSL: Exactly. But as for us, the one who wore his cap stylishly,

S.FORM: colo nuba kɛdzaŋba, sim nuba kɛdzaŋba,
S.TRANSL: who wore a pretty blouse, a pretty skirt,

S.FORM: khamdaŋba kɔ mɛːndu. anigɛ kɔ abhedaŋba phɛllɛ alla thiklɛŋ yaˀ raːktigɛ,
S.TRANSL: that wasn't our kind — the way we were, we danced one day,

S.FORM: yammu niyaːn sumyaːn lɛ thiklɛŋ laːktumbɛ,
S.TRANSL: and then we danced again after two or three days,

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛaŋ niyaːn sumyaːn yaˀ araːk abekkaŋ kɔ
S.TRANSL: and then after we'd gone on dancing two or three days,

S.FORM: tap phɛːnba mɔnannaŋ nuba ni tɛt lətchə .
S.TRANSL: why, even an ugly person came to look good.

S.FORM: nuba ni tɛt tərə aphno maya prem bəs pa cok mɛtmuna o.
S.TRANSL: They come to look good — you've fallen in love, let's say.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɔ. khɔmbhɛaŋ anigɛ kɔ khɔmbhɔ yaˀ raːktigɛ pegigɛ'llɛ
S.TRANSL: Right. That way when we went on dancing

S.FORM: nuba tap phɛːnba kunara o mɛmmɛtpa anigɛ kɔ.
S.TRANSL: we didn't look whether her face was beautiful or ugly.

S.FORM: sor aŋ nuba tap phɛːnba khɔmdaŋba anigɛ o mɛmmɛtpa.
S.TRANSL: Her voice, too, we didn't even consider if it was beautiful.

S.FORM: əgaɖi ko cələn nuba.
S.TRANSL: The old way was good.

S.FORM: lɛplɔˀ laːtmaŋ yammu yaˀ raːksɛ lasigɛaŋ anigɛ paːn khɔmbhɔ — lɔːn pekma hoptɛ.
S.TRANSL: Once we went right there, once we started dancing, our rule was, there was no going out.

S.FORM: ɛmbha lasigɛaŋ kɔ yaˀ raːktigɛ the! — khɔmbha palammɛn paːttumbɛrɔ teˀrumbɛ.
S.TRANSL: We started, we danced, we went on singing the songs,

S.FORM: paːttumbɛrɔ teˀrumbɛ khɔmbhɛaŋ kɔ jəba seˀmat yusɛ kɔrɔ lɔːnmunaba.
S.TRANSL: we went on singing and then, if we had to pee we went out,

S.FORM: hi yusɛ kɔrɔ lɔːnmunaba.
S.TRANSL: if we had to shit we went out,

S.FORM: hi seˀmat ni mɛyunɛn phɔgɔrɔ ɛmbha yaːkmunaba. nam taːttaːtchaŋ yaːkmunaba ni.
S.TRANSL: but if we didn't we stayed, even until daybreak.

S.FORM: attiatti thaŋb'ɛnnu atti mɛnchiaŋ mɔre nam taːttaːt yaˀ raːksi
S.TRANSL: If a young man and a girl danced for a long time, until dawn,

S.FORM: khan phaŋ khunchi nurik waˀsiba ani bicar cokma poŋ.
S.TRANSL: we had to think that that couple got along well.

S.FORM: khamdaŋba wayɛ ɛmbha nam taːttaːtchaŋ yaːkmunabaasi hi seˀmat mɛllɔːntarik.
S.TRANSL: That's how we were — staying on even as the sun rose — until they had to pee.

S.FORM: ɛmbhɛllɛ khɛni abhedaŋba kisim abhebhɛllɛ abhedaŋba kɛlaːktum kɔ phɛaŋ sen tonɛba.
S.TRANSL: So I am asking you how you dance.

S.FORM: ɛmbhɛllɛ kɔ cɛːtcik ci ku sor kɛnuˀb'ɛn thik tumu phɔgɔrɔ sɔpma yaˀ raːk.
S.TRANSL: Well, if a man meets someone who has a nice voice, he'll dance a while,

S.FORM: nəbhəe dekhi cəĩ khannɛn yaˀ mɛraːknɛn.
S.TRANSL: otherwise he doesn't dance.

S.FORM: atti thik mɛ-- — attin ci ku sor kɛnuˀma mɛnchia yaːk, khɔnnɛn — khɔnnɛnnu laːktuŋŋi.
S.TRANSL: Whichever woman has a nice voice, [I think:] will I dance with her?

S.FORM: attin ci numa mɛnchiahaˀ, atti'llɛ khallɛ ci caŋŋɛn məilo dəilo mɛdzaksun,
S.TRANSL: One who is somewhat pretty, one who wears clothes that aren't all dirty,

S.FORM: caŋ cinuba caksu, ɛmbhɛba tatan pɔːtthaŋ khuːksu,
S.TRANSL: one who wears nice clothes, who wears a tartan headscarf,

S.FORM: khɔnnu rɔt — khɔnnɛnnu rɔt yaˀ mɛraːk ɛmbhɛllɛ cəĩ .
S.TRANSL: they only dance with them, nowadays.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɔ. iŋgaaŋ khɔmdaŋba nisuŋŋaŋsa sen tonɛ.
S.TRANSL: Right. I've seen this so I'm asking you.

S.FORM: khɔmdaŋba mɛwaˀ. khan kudopma kɛbaːttu rətchə khɛnɛ.
S.TRANSL: that's the way they are, you've told it straight.

S.FORM: khamdaŋba ɛmbhɛllɛ mɔna cəĩ nuba caha mɛdzogɛ.
S.TRANSL: They only want nice-looking ones.

S.FORM: ku sor aŋ nuba kɛlɔːnbahaˀ, caŋŋaŋ nuba kɛdzaŋbahaˀ, khɔmdaŋbanu yaˀ kɛraːktɛ rətchə .
S.TRANSL: one who's voice comes out nicely, ones who wear nice clothes — that's the kind they dance with.

S.FORM: anigɛ khɔmdaŋba hoptɛ. khɔmbhɛllɛ sen tonɛba.
S.TRANSL: We weren't like that. So I'm asking you.

S.FORM: yammu ɛmbhɛllɛ khɛni kɛlɔˀri, kɛbaːttum palam.
S.TRANSL: Now again you do like this, you sing the words,

S.FORM: khɛni kɔ "aˀaˀaˀ nuˀuˀu" kɛlɔˀri.
S.TRANSL: you all sing like this : a' a' a' nu' u' u

S.FORM: anigɛ kɔ khɔmdaŋba hoptɛ.
S.TRANSL: We had nothing like that.

S.FORM: sor uːksumbɛ kenba khɔmbhɛ kɔ — "aaii eeee eeeeeeee" lɔt khɔmdaŋba uːŋmunaba sor ni wayɛ.
S.TRANSL: We just drew out our voices long like this aaaaiiii eeee eeeee — drawing out the voice like that.

S.FORM: khɔmdaŋba.
S.TRANSL: Like that.

S.FORM: khɛni ɛmbhɛllɛ kɔ "aˀaˀaˀa ɔˀɔˀɔˀ" kɛlɔˀri.
S.TRANSL: You all sound like this: aq aq aq oq oq oq.

S.FORM: khannɛn cəĩ aŋ yakma yak rətchə mu paːn.
S.TRANSL: Still the meaning is there, inside.

S.FORM: kusiŋ kɛniːttum khɛni. iŋga kɔ kusiŋ mɛniːtnan.
S.TRANSL: You all understand it, but I don't.

S.FORM: khɔnnɛn cəĩ ɛmbhɔ.
S.TRANSL: It's like this.

S.FORM: alla asenba khɔdakmirɛ kɔ abhe mɛdzɛksu?
S.TRANSL: How did the old-timers say the words?

S.FORM: alla ɛmbhɛllɛ kɔ səttejug — səttejug ɛllɛ alla yo pha theaŋ theaŋ lɛksɛ.
S.TRANSL: Back then in the golden age — now everything has changed.

S.FORM: alla theaŋ theaŋ lɛŋ khɔn mɛbaːttuba iŋga khɛpsuŋba jəsto ro.
S.TRANSL: Now everything is different, I've heard them say.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛllɛ iŋga kudzɛk ɛmbha khambekkɛn ni cɛlɛk! lɛksɛba ittuŋŋaŋ
S.TRANSL: Then I think, really, the earth itself has turned over,

S.FORM: ɛmbhɔ aphno bhasa ŋ lɛŋba rətchə ,
S.TRANSL: and so our language, changes as well.

S.FORM: theaŋ theaŋ lɛŋ,
S.TRANSL: Everything changes.

S.FORM: aphno caŋ, boli n lɛ bhasa yaŋ,
S.TRANSL: Our clo— our language also,

S.FORM: ɛmdaŋba caŋwaːn lɛŋ — caŋm'ɛnnaŋ jəmmə lɛŋba rətchə .
S.TRANSL: Clothing changes — the clothing we wear changes.

S.FORM: tərə iŋga khɔnnɛn cəĩ alla ɛmbhɔ poŋ pek phɔ iŋga mɛnniɛ wayaŋ.
S.TRANSL: I hadn't seen that this was happening,

S.FORM: alla sal — ɛmbhɔ ni — salinda sa ni tɛtpa.
S.TRANSL: but now year after year it can be seen.

S.FORM: tərə khɔmbha thaŋb'ɛn mɛnchia waˀmuna'llɛ
S.TRANSL: But when you young men and woman are together,

S.FORM: khɛnɛ yaŋ nɛnɛtchi —khɛnɛ nɛtchi kɛlɔːttu kɔrɔ iŋga nɛtchi lɔːttuŋ.
S.TRANSL: if you take out two rupees each — if you take out two rupees, I take out two rupees.

S.FORM: tho cummɛllɛ nɛtchi lɔːttu, na cummɛllɛ nɛtchi lɔːttu. khɔmbhɔ jəmmə rɛ lɔːtmunaŋ
S.TRANSL: Our friend up above takes out two rupees, the one over here takes out two rupees. So all pay up.

S.FORM: khɔnnɛn tɔŋmunasiŋŋaŋ mɛːnda thik taːtmunaŋ
S.TRANSL: When everyone has agreed, we get a goat,

S.FORM: khɔmbhɔ phudoŋ pimunasi, thi pimunasiba cələn əghi wayɛ əghi anigɛ.
S.TRANSL: we give them hospitality, we give them beer — that was our custom, before.

S.FORM: thi purumsimbɛ. phudoŋ purumsimbɛ.
S.TRANSL: We gave them beer, we gave them hospitality.

S.FORM: yaˀs'yaˀ wa mɛyuktuaŋ kɔ besar ci mɛdhɛktu.
S.TRANSL: They would soak some rice and put in a little turmeric.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛaŋ kɔ khallɛ khɔllɛ hərandi mɛdhɛktuaŋ kɔ hiːktaŋba mɛdzoguaŋ kɔ
S.TRANSL: They would put in turmeric and make it yellow

S.FORM: khiu cɛ mɛdhɛktuaŋ kɔ mɛnɔyu. mɛnɔyuaŋ kɔ
S.TRANSL: and they would put in a bit of ghee and fry it.

S.FORM: khandzi mɛnɛssu mɛburusi. kəhile kɔ —
S.TRANSL: They would serve up a little of that sometimes.

S.FORM: kəhile kɔ ku bela kɔ kha — wadhiːnnaŋ mɛburusi.
S.TRANSL: Sometimes they would give eggs too.

S.FORM: khɔmdaŋba mɛburusiba nisuŋŋaŋ anigɛaŋ purumsimbɛ əghi khɔmbhɔ yaˀ raːktigɛ'llɛ.
S.TRANSL: I saw them give such things, we too would give them things, before, when we danced.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɔ pim'nasi phudoŋ — phudoŋ pim'nasi — khɛni phudoŋ kɛbiasii kɛmbiasinni khɛni cəĩ ?
S.TRANSL: Such hospitality — do you all give each other hospitality or don't you?

S.FORM: phudoŋ — phudoŋŋɛllɛ cələn əjhəi waˀ khɔnnɛn.
S.TRANSL: Gifts — the custom of hospitality is still around.

S.FORM: waˀi?
S.TRANSL: Is it?

S.FORM: waˀ. theaŋ hoppɛllɛ abhɛllɛ khunchi alla jəstəi tho amuːt mɛːnni?
S.TRANSL: It is. Why wouldn't it be? Now suppose they invite us up there, OK?

S.FORM: alla amuːttaŋ khunchi ni yapmi phudoŋ mɛbɛrɛ phɔgɔrɔ
S.TRANSL: Now if they invite us and give us hospitality,

S.FORM: alla aniaŋ egaŋ uːtmasiaŋ uhi khan purəi pim'nasi poksɛ.
S.TRANSL: we, too, afterwards, we have to invite them and give them fully the same.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɔ.
S.TRANSL: Right.

S.FORM: — khunchi jəsto mɛdzogu.
S.TRANSL: It's whatever they do.

S.FORM: khunchi khannɛn ni amɛmbinɛn phɔgɔrɔ,
S.TRANSL: If they don't give it to us —

S.FORM: thi rɔt ambɛrɛ camre therɔt ambɛrɛ phɔgɔrɔ aniaŋ uhi .
S.TRANSL: If they only give us beer, if they only give us rice-cake, we do the same.

S.FORM: uhi khɔnnɛn cələn cokma poksɛ.
S.TRANSL: That's what we have to do.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛllɛsa. khunchi ambɛrɛ gɔ khunchi ambib'ɛn yaːppa pimasi poŋŋi,
S.TRANSL: In that case, do we have to give them the same amount as they give us?

S.FORM: khunchi ambib'ɛnnu lɛ ciyɔnba pimasi poŋŋi,
S.TRANSL: or do we have to give them a little more?

S.FORM: khunchi ambib'ɛnnu lɛ cidzuːkpa pimasi poŋŋi? khɔmbhɔ khan sen tonɛba — khɛnɛ ɛmbhɛllɛ abheba kɛmbiri kɔ phɛaŋ.
S.TRANSL: or do we have to give them a little less? Nowadays what do you do? — that's what I'm asking.

S.FORM: khɔn ɛmbhɛ ni. allo alla car dharni pa ambisi — mɛːnni?
S.TRANSL: It's like this. Now they give us four dharnis — OK?

S.FORM: anchi alla — anchi cum aboksɛsi mɛːnni?
S.TRANSL: Now we — we two are friends, right?

S.FORM: thik mɛnchia lɛ auːttɛsi.
S.TRANSL: A woman has invited us.

S.FORM: abesiaŋ kɔ alla tyestəi car dharni pãc dharni pa alla ambɛrɛsi ho ki ?
S.TRANSL: We go and they give us four or five dharnis, right?

S.FORM: khɔmbhɔ.
S.TRANSL: Right.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛllɛ ambɛrɛsillɛ alla khɔn lɔt kɔ nuːkma mɛnuːrɛn.
S.TRANSL: Now what she gave us, it won't do give only the same amount in return.

S.FORM: khɔn bhənda dharni nɛtchi bərta pa o — khɔnnu lɛ ciyɔnba.
S.TRANSL: It has to be two dharnis more — it has to be a little more.

S.FORM: tərə dharni lisi kɛbɔtpa ambisi kɔrɔ chə dharni pa sat dharni pa səmmə ani kokmaŋ kɔ —
S.TRANSL: If they give us four dharnis, we have to go up to six or seven dharnis.

S.FORM: thinaŋ cɛːtci yɔnba mɛttɛr'ba.
S.TRANSL: The beer, too, has to be a bit more.

S.FORM: cɛːtci yɔnba. thinaŋ khɔmbha kokma poksɛ.
S.TRANSL: A bit more. We have to add in some beer.

S.FORM: alla phudoŋ ambisib'ɛnnaŋ kokmaŋ kɔ pimasi poŋ.
S.TRANSL: We have to give more than what they give us.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɔgɔrɔ khɛni paːnnɛn lɔt ni, khɛni palam paːnnɛn lɔt ni, sor ɛn lɔt ni khɔmbha kɛuːksummɛllɛ ci bhinnəi kɛuːksum lətchə həi ?
S.TRANSL: In that case, it's only your words — only the words of your songs — only when you draw out your voices that you draw them out a little differently, right?

S.FORM: tərə əghi anigɛ uːksumbɛ'nnu mɛdɔŋnɛnnɛllɛ sen tonɛba.
S.TRANSL: It's because it isn't like the way we sang that I asked you.

S.FORM: khɔn anigɛaŋ asen anigɛaŋ kɔ koktumbɛaŋ purumsimbɛ — uhi .
S.TRANSL: For the rest, we, too, gave gifts adding a little — the same way.

S.FORM: khunchi mɛbirigɛb'ɛnnu lɛ cɛːtci yɔnba kokmaŋ pimasi poŋ.
S.TRANSL: One has to add a little more to what they've given us.

S.FORM: khunchi ambiba rəksi nu lɛ cɛːtci yɔllik cɛːtci yoˀmaŋ, cɛːtci yɔllik cokmaŋ pimasi pimasi poŋ.
S.TRANSL: One has to add a bit more alcohol to what they've given us, and give it to them.

S.FORM: tərə khunchi rəksi n thuŋma tema poŋ, jəmmə cum tɔŋmunasiŋŋaŋ kɔ ayuŋ — ha'tmu
S.TRANSL: And we must drink up their alcohol — we all get together and drink.

S.FORM: cumluŋ cokma poksɛ, cumdzum — cumluŋ adzokkaŋ khannɛtmu tɔŋmasiŋŋaŋ thuŋma.
S.TRANSL: We have to have a discussion among friends, to discuss it and then get together and drink.

S.FORM: yammu akkhɛn jəna anda — wayɛ — awaˀ, yaˀ kɛraːkpa, khan jəmmə rɛ yammu
S.TRANSL: However many we are — dancers — all

S.FORM: uhi lɔːtmaŋ kɔ yammu iŋmaŋ khatmu cɛːtci kokmaŋ pimunasiba kɔ.
S.TRANSL: get out the same amount and buy it and give it to them, adding a little.

S.FORM: asennaŋ wayɛ anigɛ yaˀ raːktigɛ'llɛaŋ.
S.TRANSL: It was like that before too, when we danced.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɔ khɔncha khɛnɛ sen tonɛba khɔn tə ho .
S.TRANSL: That's why I asked about that in particular.

S.FORM: khɔn kɔ tɔŋ lətchə .
S.TRANSL: That is the same, it turns out.

S.FORM: tərə khɛni ha sor ɛn lɔt ni mɛdɔŋnɛn, khɛni —
S.TRANSL: Only your voices aren't the same.

S.FORM: anigɛ kɔ khɔmbhɔ kenba uːksumbɛ.
S.TRANSL: Back then we drew our voices out long.

S.FORM: khɛni ɛmbhɛllɛ kenba kɛnuːksummɛn tərə —
S.TRANSL: You don't draw them out.

S.FORM: ɛmbhɛ poŋ phɔŋai. sor ɛn kɔ — sor ɛn kɔ cɛːtci alla lɛksɛ həgi ?
S.TRANSL: That's the way it is, uncle. The voices have changed now, right?

S.FORM: tərə palam kɔ uhi lɔtthik.
S.TRANSL: But the song is the same.

S.FORM: palam lɔtthik — uhi palammɛnaŋ tɔŋ.
S.TRANSL: It's one song — the song is the same.

S.FORM: tərə hɔnɛ — alla anigɛ khɔmbhɛ sor ɛn lɛksɛ'llɛ khan palam ərko paːtmunaba, palam kɔ lɔtthik.
S.TRANSL: Our voice has changed — the way of singing it is different — but the song is the same.

S.FORM: tərə əgaɖi b'ɛnnu ɛmbhɛllɛb'ɛn mɛdɔŋnɛn cɛ kɔ.
S.TRANSL: Today's and the old-time one doesn't quite agree.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛa.
S.TRANSL: Right.

S.FORM: mɛdɔŋnɛn khɔmbhɛllɛ.
S.TRANSL: They don't agree.

S.FORM: ɛmbhɛllɛ hunu kɔ asen phɔŋasi yarik anigɛ cəĩ mɛdɔŋigɛn khas .
S.TRANSL: Actually, we aren't the same as your generation, uncle.

S.FORM: theaŋ mɛdɔŋigɛn həgi — ə̃ə̃ — əgaɖi phɛ khɛni səllah yɔndɛ.
S.TRANSL: The reason we aren't the same — before, your consensus was more important.

S.FORM: anigɛ kɔ allo — alla sat jəna the səllah tɔŋŋasigɛ'llɛ, sat jəna 'tmu — ɛɛ —
S.TRANSL: We nowadays, if seven of us agree on a plan, out of the seven

S.FORM: sumsi, lisi, ŋasi, khɔmbhɔ rɔt anigɛ səllah akkho tɔŋ.
S.TRANSL: three, four, five — later only that many of us will still agree —

S.FORM: "khatmu iŋga mɛlɔːtnan ho !
S.TRANSL: "I'm not paying for that, hey!

S.FORM: iŋga kudzɛkpa ɛmbhɔ rɔt caŋba ho !"
S.TRANSL: I only ate this much, really!"

S.FORM: thiklɛ allo amɛt ho .
S.TRANSL: one of them will tell us.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛllɛ o — ɛmbhɛllɛ anigɛ sərsəllah mɛdɔŋigɛn hindza phɛkkɛtmu.
S.TRANSL: So nowadays we don't get solidarity, among the group of young men.

S.FORM: asen anigɛ kɔ celi sɔmmarɛ kudɔŋba lɔːttumbɛ.
S.TRANSL: Before, we paid equally, clan-brothers and clan-sisters. [Clan-siblings can not dance together, but they used to go together to meet boys and girls of another clan.]

S.FORM: sɔmmab'ɛllɛ lɔːtma bərabər celi 'llɛaŋ lɔːtmunaba.
S.TRANSL: The sisters would pay however much the brothers paid.

S.FORM: bərabər lɔːttumbɛaŋ kudɔŋba lɔːttumbɛaŋ purumsimbɛ.
S.TRANSL: We all took out the same amount and gave it to them.

S.FORM: khunchiaŋ celi sɔmma mɛbhɛrɛ. anigɛaŋ celi sɔmma pegigɛ.
S.TRANSL: They [the other clan] came, both brothers and sisters. We went, brothers and sisters together.

S.FORM: khɛnɛ kɛbaːttub'ɛn kusik təmər khola kɛyuŋba, saˀudɛn kɛyuŋbanu khɔmbhɛ yaˀ raːktigɛ wayigɛ.
S.TRANSL: Just as you said, back then we would dance with people from the Tamur Khola, from Sauden.

S.FORM: liŋdhɛp kɛyuŋmanuaŋ yaˀ raːktigɛ. khɔmbhɛ wayigɛ.
S.TRANSL: We danced with people from Lingthep.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɔ phudoŋ piasigɛ'llɛ kudɔŋba lɔːttumbɛ anigɛ.
S.TRANSL: When we gave each other gifts, we all paid equally.

S.FORM: khɛniaŋ kudɔŋba kɛlɔːttummiya lɔːtmuna kɔ.
S.TRANSL: You all pay equally too, I suppose, as far as paying goes.

S.FORM: tərə kohi kɔ mɛllɔːtmuna mɛwaˀ, kohi kɔ kɛlɔːtpa mɛwaˀ kohi rɛ.
S.TRANSL: But there are always some who pay, and some who don't.

S.FORM: kohi rɛ thi rɔt kɛdhuŋba yaˀ raːk, mɛndzo kɛlaːkpa. khunɛ kɔ —
S.TRANSL: Some mainly drink beer, and as for dancing, they're mediocre dancers.

S.FORM: khɔmbha pəisa mɛllɔːtmunaŋ mɛwaˀ.
S.TRANSL: And there are some who don't take out their money.

S.FORM: kohi khɔmbha kɛlɔːtpa awaˀ mɔna.
S.TRANSL: Some of us pay.

S.FORM: mɔna'llɛ mɔna andɔŋnɛnchaba — khɔmbhɔ.
S.TRANSL: We people aren't the same.

S.FORM: andɔŋnɛn.
S.TRANSL: We're not the same.

S.FORM: khɔmdaŋba mɛwaˀ. khɔn kudopma kɛbaːttu a.
S.TRANSL: They're like that. You're telling it straight.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛllɛ tɔŋ tərə anigɛ kɔ — ɛmbhɛllɛ kɔ — khɔmdaŋba alla cələn poksɛ pe mɛtma o.
S.TRANSL: That fits. But our custom — nowadays — its become like that, let's say.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛllɛ jəti b'ɛn cəĩ alla asen phɔŋasirɛ ɛmbha na, tho mɛnchiarɛ kɛmuːtti'llɛ
S.TRANSL: Back then, in your generation, uncle, if women invited you up somewhere, over somewhere,

S.FORM: celi nu sɔmmanu kɛbegi mɛːnni?
S.TRANSL: you went together, clan-brothers and sisters, no?

S.FORM: khɔmbhɔ.
S.TRANSL: Yes.

S.FORM: kɛbegi'llɛ gəjəb lɛ səllah kɛdɔŋiaŋ kɛbegi.
S.TRANSL: When you went, you really agreed together and you went.

S.FORM: ɛmbhɛllɛ gɔ abhedaŋba waˀ phɛllɛ — ə̃ə̃ —
S.TRANSL: Now, how it is,

S.FORM: anigɛ — igɔrɔ anigɛ sɔmmaba ek lɔt pegigɛ, celi mɛdeˀrumsimbɛn.
S.TRANSL: we — either we clan-brothers go by ourselves, we don't take the girls,

S.FORM: celi rɛaŋ na, tho khunchi thaŋb'ɛn lɛ mɛuːttusi phɔgɔrɔ
S.TRANSL: and the clan-sisters, if some young men invite them up, over somewhere,

S.FORM: uhi khunchi ek mɛbek.
S.TRANSL: it's the same — they go by themselves.

S.FORM: sɔmmaba khunchi caha mɛdzoknɛn.
S.TRANSL: They don't want their clan-brothers.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛllɛ khɔmdaŋba cələn poksɛaŋ waˀ ɛmbhɛllɛ.
S.TRANSL: That's become the custom nowadays.

S.FORM: əgaɖi khɛni kɔ celi sɔmmanu laŋ mɛŋghekkɛ khɛni kɛmbeginba.
S.TRANSL: Before, unless the brothers and sisters went together, you didn't go.

S.FORM: tərə anigɛ kɔ ɛmbhɛllɛ kɔ celi sɔmmanu sorik laŋ khekma hop — khɔnnɛn cəĩ .
S.TRANSL: But now, with us, there's no question of brothers and sisters going together, as far as that's concerned.

S.FORM: tərə khɛni khɔmbhɔ yaˀ raːksɛ kɛbegiaŋ kɛdɛi'llɛ ɛmbhɛllɛ kɛipsi.
S.TRANSL: But you all, when you've gone dancing and you come back, nowadays you go to bed.

S.FORM: pa, marɛ mɛnisurɔ yaˀ raːksɛ kɛbegiaŋ yammu kɛdɛi.
S.TRANSL: With the knowledge of your parents, you go dancing and then you come back.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɔ kɛipsi. puŋŋaŋ kɛmbegin. kɛngisin a khɛni ɛmbhɛllɛ.
S.TRANSL: And then you go to bed. You don't go to the work-party. You're not afraid, nowadays.

S.FORM: anigɛ khɔmbha asen kɔ abhe lɔˀrigɛ phɛllɛ —
S.TRANSL: We, before, how we were —

S.FORM: alla himmu panu marɛ mɛnnisumba anigɛ yaˀ raːksɛ pekm'ɛllɛ.
S.TRANSL: Without our parents knowing, when we went dancing,

S.FORM: celi sɔmma anda tɔŋmasiŋ poŋ, cumdzum tɔŋmasiŋ poŋ, khɔmbhɛaŋ kɔ pegigɛ.
S.TRANSL: the boys and girls had to agree, all the friends had to agree, and then we went.

S.FORM: tərə akkho tɛigɛ'llɛ bela pa maŋ mɛimmaŋ mɛnɛ.
S.TRANSL: Later, when we came back, our parents were already sleeping.

S.FORM: anigɛ mikkaŋ mɛyunɛnba.
S.TRANSL: We didn't fall asleep.

S.FORM: lɛplɔrik tɔːk mɛbirigɛaŋ kɔ kaːŋ yaŋŋasigɛ.
S.TRANSL: Directly they gave us food, we took up our hoes.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛaŋ kɔ puŋ thasigɛ. pegigɛ.
S.TRANSL: Then we set out for the work-party. We went.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛaŋ khatmu immaŋ nɛm'ɛllɛ, alla celi sɔmma —
S.TRANSL: Then over there, if we slept, the clan-brothers and sisters —

S.FORM: alla celi immaŋ nɛ'llɛ sɔmma phɛllɛ yaˀ ɔːguba.
S.TRANSL: Now if the sisters were asleep, it was the brothers who would hoe,

S.FORM: yammu akkho yammu — yammu celi n pokkaŋ khunɛ ɔːgu'llɛ sɔmma ɔːkmunaba, palo palo ɔːkmunaba.
S.TRANSL: and again later, when the sisters got up and hoed, they would hoe by turns.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛaŋ himmu mu pa marɛaŋ napmi mɛndɔrɛn, kusiŋ mɛnniːttun.
S.TRANSL: So at home our parents didn't scold us, they didn't even know.

S.FORM: ɛmbhɛllɛ kɔ khɛni kɔ kɛipsi, kɛdɛiaŋ kɔ.
S.TRANSL: Nowadays you just sleep, when you come back.

S.FORM: khɔmdaŋba iŋga nisuŋ.
S.TRANSL: That's how I see it.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɔ ɛtmu paŋbhe'tmu khɔmdaŋba kɛwayi ro! ɛmbhɛllɛ.
S.TRANSL: That's the way you are here in the village, nowadays!

S.FORM: wayigɛ tərə khannɛn — ə̃ə̃ —
S.TRANSL: We are, but

S.FORM: khɔmlɔrik uhile kɔ phɔŋasi kɔ khɔmlɔrik kɛbegi — yaˀ raːksɛ kɛbegi kɛdɛiaŋ kɔ
S.TRANSL: before, uncle, when you went dancing and came back,

S.FORM: ɛmbha lɛplɔrik kam ɛtmu kɛdhasi.
S.TRANSL: you set out directly to work.

S.FORM: tərə ɛmbhɛllɛ kɔ anigɛ kɔ khɔn ambhɔŋasirɛ kusiktaŋba asen khɔmdaŋba cələn hop.
S.TRANSL: But nowadays, we don't have a custom like your generation's, uncle.

S.FORM: ɛmbhɛllɛ kɔ thikthik — tərə ɛmbhɛllɛ kɔ thikthik lɔt mɛwaˀ, khɔmdaŋba. thikthik lɔt mɛwaˀ.
S.TRANSL: Now there are one or two like that. There are only one or two.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛllɛ ɛmbhɛllɛ kɔ lɛplɔrik yaˀ raːksɛ pekmaŋ tamaŋ kɔ kɛimb'ɛn ɛmbha mɛimmaŋ mɛnɛ.
S.TRANSL: When they go dancing and come back, the sleepers stay sleeping.

S.FORM: ə̃ — kam coksɛ kɛbekp'ɛn, cɛːtcik khunchi pa ma kɛgitp'ɛn cəĩ nə .
S.TRANSL: The ones who go to work, it's the ones who are a little afraid of their parents.

S.FORM: alla — allo — alla ambhɔŋarɛ kɛsa cəndre aŋ kɔ alla jəstəi bəjar yaˀ raːksɛ pek mɛːnni?
S.TRANSL: Now uncle, suppose your son Chandre goes to the fair to dance, OK?
Hmm.

S.FORM: pekkɛllɛ — xxx ho — ain kɔ iŋga ɛmdaŋba iskul ɛtmu kam aŋ kɔttuŋ.
S.TRANSL: When he goes — "Oh, I have some work to do at school today."

S.FORM: ain kɔ ɛmdaŋba — ə̃ə̃ — yaˀ ɔːkma the yaːllek phɔnmasi theaŋ kɔttuŋsiŋ".
S.TRANSL: "Today I have to supervise some laborers hoeing."

S.FORM: tərə khɔnnɛn cəĩ "alla immaŋ nɛma phɛllɛ amba kɛdziːtpa, allo adɔn ahip asɛttiya"
S.TRANSL: [He thinks:] "If I sleep in, my father is strict, he'll abuse me, he'll hit me, he'll kill me,"

S.FORM: lɔˀaŋ kɔ khunɛ kɔ hoitlɔrik pek.
S.TRANSL: he thinks, and he goes off immediately.

S.FORM: tərə khɔnnɛn uhi ho , alla ani pa ma lɛ cɛːtcik yɔŋma sɛtmasi ci pa ma kɛdziːtp'ɛllɛ ni — mɛmma poŋ.
S.TRANSL: But its the same — It's like that if the parents are a little strict, if they inspire fear.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɔ sarɛaŋ amgit — amgitpa ɛmbha.
S.TRANSL: Then the children fear us, they fear us like that.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛa amgittaŋ, kam ɛnnaŋ mɛdzoguaŋ,
S.TRANSL: They fear us, and they work.

S.FORM: tərə anigɛ khɔmbha hal toksigɛ'llɛ,
S.TRANSL: But when we plowed,

S.FORM: anigɛ hal toksumbɛb'ɛn yarik khɛni niyaːn rɔt kɛdoksum.
S.TRANSL: The amount that we plowed, you all can only plow in two days.

S.FORM: anigɛ thikyaːn lɛ toksumbɛb'ɛn khɛni niyaːn lɛ kɛdoksum.
S.TRANSL: The amount we plowed in one day, you plow in two days.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛllɛ pa ɛmbhɛllɛba khɛni pa the'tmu khɔmbhɔ khɛni mɛyaːknɛnbai khɛni sɔkma.
S.TRANSL: Your father's — as much as was your father had in him — uh — you don't have the stamina.

S.FORM: mɛŋgɔrɔ kudɔŋba toŋma kɛboŋba, asenba yarik.
S.TRANSL: Otherwise you should be able to plow as much as the old-timers.

S.FORM: yammu mɛbaːttu'llɛ asen ambasirɛ mɛdoksuba yarik iŋga "khɛnɛ kɛndoksun" tərə ammarɛaŋ khɔmbhɔ mɛttaŋ.
S.TRANSL: They used to say, compared to the amount my father's generation plowed, "You don't plow as much." My mother used to tell me that.

S.FORM: "kɛmbarɛ toksuba yarik khɛnɛ hal kɛndoksun" mɛttaŋ.
S.TRANSL: "You don't plow as much as your father used to plow," she told me.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛlɔrik cɛksu.
S.TRANSL: That's what they said.

S.FORM: luŋdzɔŋ ciluŋ mɛsɛttuba, khunchi siŋ mɛbɔksuba mɛdzɛksu'llɛ iŋgaŋ mɛnchukpa.
S.TRANSL: And when they said how much stone wall they laid, or how much wood they carried, I was unable to do it.

S.FORM: ambarɛ pɔksuba yarik ambarɛ luŋ lɛksuaŋ nɛssuba yarik iŋga nɛma mɛnchukpa.
S.TRANSL: The amount my father carried, the amount of rock my father turned over and laid down, I couldn't do it.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛllɛ asenba mɔna cigɛdhumbaasi.
S.TRANSL: The old-timers back then were stronger.

S.FORM: kɛdhumbasi tərə khɔn kɔ ɛmbhɔ poŋ phɔŋai …
S.TRANSL: They were strong. But it is like this, uncle.

S.FORM: tərə asenba mɔnahaˀ bhənda lɛ khɔmbhɛ kɛdhumba mɛwayɛ, waˀma kɔ. ɛmbhɛllɛ yammu ɛmbhɛllɛ waˀma kɔ awaˀ.
S.TRANSL: And compared to the old-timers — they were strong, as far as that goes — but now also there are some of us who are strong.

S.FORM: tərə jun jəti kam cokma jəti adhum lətchə .
S.TRANSL: The more work we do, the stronger we are, it turns out.

S.FORM: kam mɛndzokma ɛmbha mɛndzo ɛmbha waˀma phɔgɔrɔ khɔmbhɔ andhumnɛn.
S.TRANSL: If we just hang around, not doing any work, then we are not strong.

S.FORM: cɛːt thɔkkɛnna lɛt pek lətchə . lɛttaŋ kɔ cɛːt andhumnɛnba rətchə .
S.TRANSL: Our bodies go a bit to seed. They go to seed and we aren't strong.

S.FORM: abhe yɛ kɛbaːnnɛn?
S.TRANSL: What do you say?

S.FORM: khɔnnɛn khɔn kɔ ɛmbhɛdaŋba phɔŋai.
S.TRANSL: It's like this, uncle.

S.FORM: jəti phɛ ɛmbhɛllɛ kəli yug ɛllɛba anigɛ kudzɛk hindza gɔ alla khɔtyo rɔt khɔtyo rɔt ayu.
S.TRANSL: Now in the Kali Yug, we youngsters keep going downhill, further and further.

S.FORM: alla asen phɔŋasirɛ yarik ə̃ kɛdzogumba anigɛ ɛmbhɛllɛ khɔpmu mɛgɛttumbɛn.
S.TRANSL: We don't match the amount of work that your generation did before, uncle.

S.FORM: phɔŋasirɛ kɛdzamba yarikkɛtmu anigɛ ni khɔn kɛpma mɛsuktumbɛn.
S.TRANSL: We can't even match the amount that you ate.

S.FORM: anigɛ uhi khɛni mɛnchahaˀrɛ anigɛ cogumbɛba yarik khɛni mɛnchahaˀrɛ yammu kɛpma mɛnchuktun.
S.TRANSL: Similarly, your grandchildren can't match the amount of work we do.

S.FORM: khɔmbha.
S.TRANSL: Right.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛllɛ. ɛmbhɛllɛ alla səttejug asen səttejug ɛllɛ sususiba mɔna mɛdhumdɛaŋ, ɛmbhɛllɛ kəli jug ɛllɛba ləu khɔmdaŋba rɔt. rətchə .
S.TRANSL: So, the men before, who were touched by the Golden Age, were strong, but now those of the Kali Yug are only like this.

S.FORM: khɔmbha — khɔn kudopma.
S.TRANSL: Right. That's the straight story.

S.FORM: tərə ani yakthumbarɛ yakthumbanu pɛni'llɛ akkh'yarik bicar kɛdzogu?
S.TRANSL: Now, what's your opinion concerning us Limbus and the Nepalis?

S.FORM: yakthumb'ɛllɛ coaŋ coguaŋ.
S.TRANSL: The Limbu eats, and he works.

S.FORM: ɛmbhɛllɛ abhedaŋba poksɛ khɛni pɛni paːn ciyɔllik kɛbaːri.
S.TRANSL: But now, what's happened, you all speak a little more Nepali [when speaking Limbu].

S.FORM: yakthuŋ paːn cigɛmasum.
S.TRANSL: You've lost a little of the Limbu language.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛllɛ khɔllɛ abheba co khɔmdaŋba cama khɔmbhɛ ciyɔllik khɛni kɛlasi.
S.TRANSL: It's a case of ?? eating what they eat — you all have gone a bit down that road.

S.FORM: khɔpmu kɛlasi. khɔpmu kɛlasi khɔmbhɛllɛ.
S.TRANSL: You've gone that way.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛllɛ khɔmbha khɔmdaŋba thummɛn kɔ cɛːtci yɔmba cigemba kuyɛt ciyɔmb'ɛn cɛːtci thum mɛːnni?
S.TRANSL: Now as far as being strong, one who is a little bigger, a little taller, whose bones are a bit bigger, he's a bit stronger, no?

S.FORM: yɛt cuːkpa mɔna cuːkpa phɔgɔrɔ andhumnɛn a.
S.TRANSL: If one's bones are small, if one is small, one isn't strong.

S.FORM: andhumnɛn.
S.TRANSL: No.

S.FORM: cɛːtci yɔmb'ɛnnaŋ ciliːp.
S.TRANSL: One who is a bit bigger will be a bit heavier.

S.FORM: ciliːp.
S.TRANSL: He'll be heavier.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛllɛ khɔmdaŋba …
S.TRANSL: So …

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛllɛ ləu paːttɛ khɛnɛ. khɔmbhɛllɛ …
S.TRANSL: So — go ahead, speak.

S.FORM: yakthumba mɛtmunasiŋŋɛn abhedaŋba poksɛ'llɛ — yakthumba aboksɛ ani.
S.TRANSL: As to how it came about, calling ourselves "Yakthungba" — we're yakthungba.

S.FORM: yakthumba mɛtmuna yakthumbai akthumbai? ɛ nɛtchi'pmu ɛ nɛtchi'pmu.
S.TRANSL: The word "yakthungba" — is it "yakthungba" or is it "akthungba"? Between these two.

S.FORM: yakthumbai akthumbai?
S.TRANSL: Is it "yakthungba" or is it "akthungba"?

S.FORM: alla iŋga ittuŋŋɛllɛ yakthumba phɛllɛ — yakthumba kɔ mɛːndu akthuŋbai kusiktaŋ lɔˀ a.
S.TRANSL: Now that I think of it, "yakthungba" — it's not "yakthungba", it's more like "akthungba".
Hmm.

S.FORM: kudzɛkki? khɔmbhɔi? khɔmbhɔ mɛːnni ambhɔŋae?
S.TRANSL: Is it true? Is it like that? It's like that, no, uncle?

S.FORM: akthuŋba mɛtmunan cəĩ kuyaŋŋɛtmu yaktarik aktuɛ kɛthuŋb'ɛllɛ akthuŋba siktaŋba həi !
S.TRANSL: If we say "akthungba" — as long as there's something inside the pot, since one served it ["aktu"] and drank it ["thung"], it's like "akthungba" right!

S.FORM: yakthuŋba mɛtmunan abhedaŋba yak, yakthuŋba.
S.TRANSL: The expression "yakthungba" — whatever's inside ["yak"] — "yakthungba".

S.FORM: yak, yakthuŋba.
S.TRANSL: "yak", "yakthungba".

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛllɛ khɔn sen donɛba khɛnɛ.
S.TRANSL: That's what I'm asking you.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛllɛ khɔn yakthuŋba kudzɛkkaŋ ni ya khɔn.
S.TRANSL: Then indeed it must be "yakthungba".

S.FORM: alla himmu waˀthɛllik lɔt ni kɛdzab'adi, ho ki ?
S.TRANSL: We are people who eat only as long as there is ["yak"] something in the house, right?

S.FORM: yakthuŋba — akthuŋba.
S.TRANSL: "yakthungba", "akthungba".

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛllɛ jəti himmu yuŋ, ho ki ?
S.TRANSL: Whatever there is in the house,

S.FORM: yə i khyampa 'pmu yuŋ
S.TRANSL: or in the storage-pot

S.FORM: khɔnnɛn akthuŋba — yakthuŋba — akthuŋba.
S.TRANSL: "akthungba", "yakthungba", "akthungba".

S.FORM: khɔmbhɔ khɔnnɛn mɛkkaŋ kɔ cuːruba ani yakthumb'ɛllɛ.
S.TRANSL: When it's finished, it's finished for us Limbus.

S.FORM: khɔmbhɛaŋsa akthumba alla mɛlɔˀ laˀba.
S.TRANSL: Maybe that's why they say "akthungba" [??].

S.FORM: taːndik cama ɛtchindaːn cama taŋba kɔ the niŋwa'tmu mɛyaknɛn.
S.TRANSL: We have no thought for what to eat tomorrow, or the next day.

S.FORM: allo rɔt caŋŋaŋ kɔ taːndi ɛtchindaːn kɔ cama
S.TRANSL: If I've eaten just now, eating tomorrow or the next day —

S.FORM: caha mɛdzokŋan!
S.TRANSL: I don't need it!

S.FORM: ɛmbhɛdaŋba rɔt niŋwa — ani yakthuŋbarɛ niŋwa waˀba hɔmdaŋba hagi ?
S.TRANSL: Our Limbu philosophy is like that, huh?

S.FORM: sər ləu əi !
S.TRANSL: [To the linguist:] That's it, sir.
